sen.j: 孝明天皇（こうめいてんのう、天保2年6月14日（1831年7月22日） ‐ 慶応2年12月25日（1867年1月30日））は、江戸時代末期の天皇（121代、在位：弘化3年2月13日（1846年3月10日）‐ 慶応2年12月25日）。
sen.e: Emperor Komei (July 22, 1831 - January 30, 1867) was the Emperor during late Edo period. (the hundred twenty first Emperor, his reign was February 13, Koka 3 (March 10, 1846) - December 25, Keio 2)
Emperor Komei (July 22, 1831 - January 30, 1867) was the Emperor during late Edo period. (the hundred twenty first Emperor, his reign was February 13, Koka 3 (March 10, 1846) - December 25, Keio 2)
Emperor Komei (July 22, 1831 - January 30, 1867) was the Emperor during late Edo period. (the hundred twenty first Emperor, his reign was from March 10, 1846 to January 30, 1867)

sen.j: 諱は統仁（おさひと）。
sen.e: His Posthumous name was Osahito.
His Posthumous name was Osahito.
His posthumous name was Osahito.

sen.j: 幼称は煕宮（ひろのみや）。
sen.e: His childhood's name was Hironomiya.
His childhood's name was Hironomiya.
His childhood's name was Hironomiya.

sen.j: 在位中の徳川将軍は、12代徳川家慶・13代徳川家定・14代徳川家茂・15代徳川慶喜である。
sen.e: The Shogun during his reign was the twelfth Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the thirteenth Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, fourteenth Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA, fifteenth Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
The Shogun during his reign was the twelfth Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the thirteenth Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, fourteenth Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA, fifteenth Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
The Shogun during his reign was the twelfth Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the thirteenth Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, fourteenth Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA, fifteenth Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 仁孝天皇の第四皇子。
sen.e: He was Emperor Nintoku's fourth Prince
He was Emperor Nintoku's fourth Prince
He was Emperor Ninko's fourth Prince

sen.j: 養母は左大臣鷹司政凞の娘で仁孝女御（後、中宮）の鷹司祺子（新朔平門院）。
sen.e: His foster mother was Sadaijin (Minister of the left), Masahiro TAKATSUKASA's daughter, Ninko Nyogo (a high-ranking lady in the court) (later become Chugu (the second consort of an emperor)), Yasuko TAKATSUKASA. (Shinsakuheimonin)
sen.cmt: 女御→a high-ranking lady in the court; a consort of an emperor [定訳不明]
sen.e: His foster mother was Sadaijin (Minister of the left), Masahiro TAKATSUKASA's daughter, Ninko Nyogo (a high-ranking lady in the court) (later become Chugu - the second consort of an emperor), Yasuko TAKATSUKASA (Shinsakuheimonin).

His foster mother was Sadaijin (Minister of the left), Masahiro TAKATSUKASA's daughter, Ninko Nyogo (a high-ranking lady in the court) (later become Chugu - the second consort of an emperor), Yasuko TAKATSUKASA (Shinsakuheimonin).

sen.j: 実母は正親町実光の娘、仁孝典侍の正親町雅子（新待賢門院）。
sen.e: His real mother was Sanemitsu OGIMACHI's daughter, Ninko Nashinosuke (lady-in-waiting), Naoko OGIMACHI. (Shintaikenmonin)
His real mother was Sanemitsu OGIMACHI's daughter, Ninko Nashinosuke (lady-in-waiting), Naoko OGIMACHI. (Shintaikenmonin)
His real mother was Sanemitsu OGIMACHI's daughter, Ninko Nashinosuke (lady-in-waiting), Naoko OGIMACHI. (Shintaikenmonin)

sen.j: 正妃は九条尚忠の娘、英照皇太后。
sen.e: His official Empress was Hisatada KUJO's daughter, Empress Dowager Eisho.
His official Empress was Hisatada KUJO's daughter, Empress Dowager Eisho.
His official Empress was Hisatada KUJO's daughter, Empress Dowager Eisho.

tit.cmt: Biography→Brief Personal Historyに変更しました。

sen.j: 幼名は煕宮。
sen.e: His childhood' name was Hironomiya.
His childhood' name was Hironomiya.
His childhood' name was Hironomiya.

sen.j: 天保11年（1840年）に立太子し、弘化3年（1846年）の父・仁孝天皇の崩御によって践祚した。
sen.e: He became Crown Prince in 1840 and succeeded to the throne due to his father, Emperor Ninko's death in 1846.
He became Crown Prince in 1840 and succeeded to the throne due to his father, Emperor Ninko's death in 1846.
He became Crown Prince in 1840 and succeeded to the throne due to his father, Emperor Ninko's death in 1846.

sen.j: 父同様に学問好きな性格の持ち主で、その遺志を継いで公家の学問所である学習院を創立した。
sen.e: He took after his father and loved to study, he took father's will and established court nobles learning centre, Gakushuin.
He took after his father and loved to study, he took father's will and established the court nobles learning centre, Gakushuin.
He took after his father and loved to study, he took father's will and established the court nobles learning center, Gakushuin.

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）のマシュー・ペリー来航以来、幕府政治に発言力を持ち、江戸幕府大老井伊直弼が諸外国と独断で条約を結ぶとこれに不信を示し、一時は攘夷さえ表明したこともあった（文久3年（1863年）3月の攘夷勅命）。
sen.e: Since Matther Perry came to Japan in 1853, the Emperor had an influential voice in politics in the bakufu, he distrusted the incident when a chief minister [councilor] of the Tokugawa shogunate, Naosuke II of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) had an agreement with overseas countries arbitrarily, and even once, he expressed the exclusion of foreigners from Japan. (the Imperial order of exclusion of foreigners in March (1863))

Since Matthew Perry came to Japan in 1853, the Emperor had an influential voice in politics in the bakufu, he distrusted the incident when a chief minister [councilor] of the Tokugawa shogunate, Naosuke II of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) arbitrarily made agreements with overseas countries, and even once, he expressed the exclusion of foreigners from Japan (the Imperial order of exclusion of foreigners in March (1863)).

Since Matthew Perry came to Japan in 1853, the Emperor had an influential voice in politics in the bakufu, he distrusted the incident when a chief minister [councilor] of the Tokugawa shogunate, Naosuke II of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) arbitrarily made agreements with overseas countries, and even once, he expressed the exclusion of foreigners from Japan (the Imperial order of exclusion of foreigners in March (1863)).

sen.j: これを受けて下関戦争や薩英戦争が起き、日本国内では外国人襲撃など攘夷運動が荒れ狂った。
sen.e: After this Imperial order was issued, there were the Shimonoseki War and the Kagoshima Bombardment; the Satsuma (Kagoshima)-British War happened, and some foreigners were attacked by Japanese people and the movement to exclusionism was getting severe in Japan.

After this Imperial order was issued, the Shimonoseki War and the Kagoshima Bombardment; the Satsuma (Kagoshima)-British War took place, and some foreigners were attacked by Japanese people and the movement to exclusionism was becoming severe in Japan.

After this Imperial order was issued, the Shimonoseki War and the Kagoshima Bombardment; the Satsuma (Kagoshima)-British War took place, and some foreigners were attacked by Japanese people and the movement to exclusionism was becoming severe in Japan.

sen.j: 孝明天皇は攘夷の意思が激しく、妹・和宮親子内親王を第14代征夷大将軍・徳川家茂に嫁がせるなど、公武合体運動を推進し、あくまで鎖国を望んだ。
sen.e: Emperor Komei was a strong believer of an exclusionism, he let her younger sister marry to the fourteenth Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians), Iemochi TOKUGAWA, and he encouraged the movement of union of the Imperial Court and the Shogunate, he strongly wished isolation of the country.

Emperor Komei was a strong believer of exclusionism, he let his younger sister Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikakomarry to the fourteenth Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians), Iemochi TOKUGAWA, and he encouraged the movement of the union of the Imperial Court and the Shogunate, he strongly wished isolation for the country.

Emperor Komei was a strong believer of exclusionism, he let his younger sister Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako marry to the fourteenth Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Iemochi TOKUGAWA, and he encouraged the movement of the union of the Imperial Court and the Shogunate, he strongly wished isolation for the country.

sen.j: 家茂が上洛してきたときは、攘夷祈願のために賀茂神社や石清水八幡宮に行幸している。
sen.e: When Iemochi came to Kyoto, he went to Kamo-jinja Shrine and Iwashimizu hachiman-gu Shrine to pray for the bright future of the exclusionism policy.
When Iemochi came to Kyoto, he went to Kamo-jinja Shrine and Iwashimizu hachiman-gu Shrine to pray for a bright future of the exclusionism policy.
When Iemochi came to Kyoto, he went to Kamo-jinja Shrine and Iwashimizu hachiman-gu Shrine to pray for a bright future of the exclusionism policy.

sen.j: 京都守護職であった会津藩主松平容保への信任は特に厚かったといわれる。
sen.e: It was said he especially trusted the military governorship of Kyoto, the lord of the Aizu domain, Katamori MATSUDAIRA very much.
It was said he especially trusted the military governorship of Kyoto, the lord of the Aizu domain, Katamori MATSUDAIRA very much.
It was said he especially trusted the military governorship of Kyoto, the lord of the Aizu Domain, Katamori MATSUDAIRA very much.

sen.j: しかし慶応元年（1865年）、攘夷運動の最大の要因は孝明天皇の存在にあると見た諸外国海軍は艦隊を大坂湾に入れて天皇に条約の勅許を要求して、天皇も事態の深刻さを悟って条約の勅許が出される事となった。
sen.e: However navy from various overseas countries thought the cause of the movement of the exclusionism was due to the existence of Emperor Komei,and they sent a fleet to Osaka Bay and demanded Imperial sanction of the Emperor for the agreement, finally the Emperor realized how serious the situation was, he decided to issue an Imperial sanction of the agreement.

However, navies from various overseas countries thought the cause of the exclusionism movement was due to the existence of Emperor Komei, and they sent a fleet to Osaka Bay and demanded Imperial sanction of the Emperor for the agreement, finally the Emperor realized how serious the situation was, he decided to issue an Imperial sanction of the agreement.

However in 1865, navies from various overseas countries thought the cause of the exclusionism movement was due to the existence of Emperor Komei, and they sent a fleet to Osaka Bay and demanded Imperial sanction of the Emperor for the agreement, finally the Emperor realized how serious the situation was, he decided to issue an Imperial sanction of the agreement.

sen.j: だが、この年には実際には宮中のみに留まったものの医学の禁止を命じるなど、保守的な姿勢は崩さなかった（もっとも、遺品として時計が残るなど、西洋文明を全く否定していたわけではない）。
sen.e: But there was yet conservative movement such as prohibition of studying medicine, although such a movement was kept within the Imperial palace. (off course the western culture was not totally denied, as you can see there was an article of watch left in the Imperial Palace.)

But there was yet a conservative movement such as the prohibition on studying medicine, although such a movement was kept within the Imperial palace. (off course western culture was not totally denied, as you can see there was a wristwatch left in the Imperial Palace.)

But there was yet a conservative movement such as the prohibition on studying medicine, although such a movement was kept within the Imperial palace. (Of course western culture was not totally denied, as you can see there was a wristwatch left in the Imperial Palace.)

sen.j: 翌 慶応2年（1866年）12月25日、義弟・家茂の後を追うように、在位21年にして崩御。
sen.e: On December 25 in 1866, the following year, the Emperor died, it seemed he followed the death of his younger brother in law, Iemochi.
On December 25 in 1866, the following year, the Emperor died, it seemed he followed the death of his younger brother in law, Iemochi.
On December 25, 1866, the following year, the Emperor died after 21 years of his reign, it seemed he followed the death of his younger brother in law, Iemochi.
sen.cmt: after 21 years of his reign補足

sen.j: 死因は天然痘と診断された。
sen.e: It was said he died of smallpox.
It was said he died of smallpox.
It was said he died of smallpox.

sen.e: Keio
Keio

sen.j: 孝明天皇と漢風諡号が贈られた。
sen.e: He received the name of Emperor Komei and the posthumous name on Chinese style.
He received the name of Emperor Komei and the posthumous name in Chinese style.
He received the name of Emperor Komei and the posthumous name in Chinese style.

sen.j: 諡を持つ最後の天皇（明治天皇以後の追号も諡号の一種とする場合もあるが、厳密には異なる）。
sen.e: He was the last Emperor who received the posthumous name. (sometimes Tsuigo is considered to be a type of posthumous name, however strictly speaking these are two different names.)
He was the last Emperor who received a posthumous name. (sometimes Tsuigo is considered to be a type of posthumous name, however strictly speaking these are two different names.)
He was the last Emperor who received a posthumous name. (Sometimes Tsuigo is considered to be a type of posthumous name, however strictly speaking these are two different names.)

sen.j: 陵墓は従来の仏式葬の石塔から古式に改められ、歴代天皇墓所の泉涌寺内に円墳を模した後月輪東山陵（のちのつきのわのひがしやまのみささぎ）が築かれた。
sen.e: The Mausoleum was changed from existing tombstone style of Buddhist rites to an old style, the round barrow, the Nochinotsukinowa Mausoleum (later called Tsukinowano higashiyamano misasagi) was established within Sennyu-ji Temple of the successive Emperor's Mausoleum.

The Mausoleum was changed from the existing tombstone style of Buddhist rites to an older style, the round barrow, the Nochinotsukinowa Mausoleum (later called Tsukinowano higashiyamano misasagi) was established within Sennyu-ji Temple of the successive Emperor's Mausoleum.

The Mausoleum was changed from the existing tombstone style of Buddhist rites to an older style, the round barrow, the Nochinotsukinowa Mausoleum (later called Tsukinowano higashiyamano misasagi) was established within Sennyu-ji Temple of the successive Emperor's Mausoleum.

sen.j: 平安京最初の天皇・桓武天皇を祀る平安神宮に、昭和15年（1940年、神武天皇即位紀元2600年）に平安京最後の天皇として合祀された。
sen.e: He was enshrined in Heian-jingu Shrine in 1940 (Emperor Jinmu's enthronement in the era of 2600), as the last emperor of the ancient capital of Heian Kyo, together with the first Emperor of the ancient capital of Heian Kyo, Emperor Kanmu.

He was enshrined in Heian-jingu Shrine in 1940 (Emperor Jinmu's enthronement in the era of 2600), as the last emperor of the ancient capital of Heian Kyo, together with the first Emperor of the ancient capital of Heian Kyo, Emperor Kanmu.

He was enshrined in Heian-jingu Shrine in 1940 (Emperor Jinmu's enthronement in the era of 2600), as the last emperor of the ancient capital of Heian Kyo, together with the first Emperor of the ancient capital of Heian Kyo, Emperor Kanmu.

sen.j: 崩御にまつわる論争
sen.e: The argument in relation to the Emperor's death
The argument in relation to the Emperor's death
The argument in relation to the Emperor's death

sen.j: 崩御に至るまでの経緯
sen.e: How the emperor passed away
How the emperor passed away
How the emperor passed away

sen.j: 慶應2年12月11日（1867年1月16日）、風邪気味であった孝明天皇は、宮中で執り行われた神事に医師たちが止めるのも聞かずに参加し、翌12日に発熱する。
sen.e: On January 16, 1867, Emperor Komei was not well as he had a flue, but he attended Shinto ritual held in the Imperial Palace although his doctors stopped him attending, on the following day (on 12th), he had a fever.

On January 16, 1867, Emperor Komei was not well as he had the flue, but he attended a Shinto ritual held in the Imperial Palace although his doctors stopped him from attending, on the following day (on 12th), he had a fever.

On January 16, 1867, Emperor Komei was not well as he had the flue, but he attended a Shinto ritual held in the Imperial Palace although his doctors stopped him from attending, on the following day (on 12th), he had a fever.

sen.j: 天皇の持病である痔を長年にわたって治療していた典薬寮の外科医・伊良子光順の日記よれば、孝明天皇が発熱した12日、天皇の執匙（日常の健康管理を行う主治医格）であった高階経由が拝診して投薬したが、翌日になっても病状が好転しなかった。
sen.e: According to the sergeant, Mitsuoki IRAKO's diary, who had been treating Emperor's chronic illness, hemorrhoids, when the Emperor Komei had fever on 12th, his a physician (equivalent to doctor) in charge of Emperors daily health check, 高階経由 did check up and gave medicine to the Emperor, but he did not get better on the following day.

According to the sergeant, Mitsuoki IRAKO's diary, who had been treating Emperor's chronic illness, hemorrhoids, when Emperor Komei had a fever on the 12th, his physician (equivalent to doctor) in charge of the Emperors daily health check, 高階経由 did check up and gave medicine to the Emperor, but he did not get better on the following day.

According to the sergeant, Mitsuoki IRAKO's diary, who had been treating Emperor's chronic illness, hemorrhoids, when Emperor Komei had a fever on the 12th, his physician (equivalent to doctor) in charge of the Emperors daily health check, 高階経由 did check up and gave medicine to the Emperor, but he did not get better on the following day.

sen.j: 14日、御典医筆頭のひとりで、中山慶子の執匙を務める山本隨が治療に参加、15日には光順も召集され、昼夜詰めきりでの拝診が行われた。
sen.e: On 14th, one of the chief doctor to an emperor and Yoshiko Nakayama's doctor to do daily check up, 山本隨 participated in Emperor's treatment, Mitsuoki was also called in on 15th, they kept on the medical examination on the Emperor during daytime and night time.
sen.cmt: 御典医筆頭→a chief doctor to an emperor [定訳不明]山本隨→[読み方不明] YAMAMOTO
sen.e: On the 14th, one of the chief doctors to the emperor and Yoshiko Nakayama's doctor who did daily check ups, 山本隨 participated in Emperor's treatment, Mitsuoki was also called in on the 15th, they continued the medical examinations on the Emperor day and night.

On the 14th, one of the chief doctors to the emperor and Yoshiko NAKAYAMA's doctor who did daily check ups, 山本隨 participated in Emperor's treatment, Mitsuoki was also called in on the 15th, they continued the medical examinations on the Emperor day and night.

sen.j: 12月16日（1月21日）、山本・高階・伊良子と、高階経由の息子・経徳の計4名で改めて拝診した結果、天皇が痘瘡（天然痘）に罹患している可能性が浮上する。
sen.e: On 21 January, after four people, Yamamoto, 高階, Mitsuoki and 高階経由's son, 経徳 did medical examination, they came across the possibility that the Emperor might have been infected with smallpox.
On 21 January, after four people, Yamamoto, 高階, Mitsuoki and 高階経由's son, 経徳 conducted medical examinations, they came across the possibility that the Emperor might have been infected with smallpox.

On January 21, after four people, Yamamoto, Takashina, Irako and 高階経由's son, Tsunenori conducted medical examinations, they came across the possibility that the Emperor might have been infected with smallpox.
sen.cmt: 日付行基高階→Takashina一般的読み方で表記しました。人名修正経徳→Tsunenori

sen.j: 執匙の高階経由は痘瘡の治療経験が乏しかったため、経験豊富な西尾兼道・久野恭（いずれも小児科医）を召集して拝診に参加させた結果、いよいよ痘瘡の疑いは強まり、17日に武家伝奏などへ天皇が痘瘡に罹ったことを正式に発表した。
sen.e: Since physician (equivalent to doctor) in charge of daily health check, 高階経由, did not have much experience treating smallpox, 西尾兼道 and 久野恭 (they both are pediatricians) who had treated smallpox before, were called in to let them participate in medical examination, there was more possibility that the Emperor might had smallpox, on 17th Imperial Palace made an official announcement to Buketenso (an Imperial official in charge of communication between the samurai and the court) that the Emperor was infected by smallpox.
sen.cmt: 西尾兼道→[読み方不明] NISHIO 久野恭→[読み方不明] KUNO
sen.e: Since the physician (equivalent to doctor) in charge of daily health checks, 高階経由, did not have much experience treating smallpox, 西尾兼道 and 久野恭 (they were both pediatricians) who had treated smallpox before, were called in to participate in the medical examination, there was more possibility that the Emperor might have smallpox, on the 17th, the Imperial Palace made an official announcement to Buketenso (an Imperial official in charge of communications between the samurai and the court) that the Emperor was infected with smallpox.

Since the physician (equivalent to doctor) in charge of daily health checks, 高階経由, did not have much experience treating smallpox, Kanemichi NISHIO and Kyo HISANO (they were both pediatricians) who had treated smallpox before, were called in to participate in the medical examination, there was more possibility that the Emperor might have smallpox, on the 17th, the Imperial Palace made an official announcement to Buketenso (an Imperial official in charge of communications between the samurai and the court) that the Emperor was infected with smallpox.
sen.cmt: 西尾兼道→Kanemichi NISHIO読み方不明ですが、一般的な読みで表記しました。久野恭→Kyo HISANO読み方不明ですが、一般的な読みで表記しました。

sen.j: これ以後、天脈拝診（実際に天皇の体に触れて診察すること）の資格を持つ13人に、西尾と久野の2人を加えた15人の典医たちを下記の3班に分けて、24時間体制での治療が始まった。
sen.e: After that 天脈拝診 (conducting medical examination by touching Emperor's body) was conducted by qualified thirteen doctors including 西尾 and 久野, total of fifteen doctors who work in the Imperial Palace, then they were separated into three groups to start twenty four hours treatment.
sen.cmt: 天脈拝診→[読み方確認できず]
sen.e: After that 天脈拝診 (conducting medical examination by touching Emperor's body) was conducted by qualified thirteen doctors including 西尾 and 久野, total of fifteen doctors who work in the Imperial Palace, then they were separated into three groups to start twenty four hours treatment.

After that 天脈拝診 (conducting medical examination by touching Emperor's body) was conducted by qualified thirteen doctors and Nishio and Hisano, total of fifteen doctors who work in the Imperial Palace, then they were separated into three groups to start twenty four hours treatment.
sen.cmt: 西尾、久野→一般的読みで表記including→and

sen.j: 第1班
sen.e: The first group
The first group
The first group

sen.j: 筆頭：藤木篤平 （従四位上 典薬権助兼伊勢守）
sen.e: The head of the group : 藤木篤平(Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) tenyaku no gon no suke (director in charge of prescribing medicine to Emperor), Isenokami (the head of Ise Province (current Mie Prefecture))
sen.cmt: 藤木篤平 →[読み方確認できず] 伊勢守→Isenokami [定訳不明]
sen.e: The head of the group: 藤木篤平(Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) tenyaku no gon no suke (director in charge of prescribing medicine to Emperor), Isenokami (the head of Ise Province - currently Mie Prefecture)

The head of the group: Atsuhira FUJIKI (Jushiinojo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) tenyaku no gon no suke (director in charge of prescribing medicine to Emperor), Isenokami (the head of Ise Province - currently Mie Prefecture))
sen.cmt: 藤木篤平→Atsuhira FUJIKI 読み方不明ですが、一般的な読みで表記しました。)補足"Jushiinoge"→"Jushiinojo "に変更しました。

伊良子光信 (Jurokuinojo (Junior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade), Awanosuke)

sen.j: 孝明天皇の公式の伝記である『孝明天皇紀』においては、典医たちは、定期的に天皇の病状を「御容態書」として定期的に発表していた。
sen.e: According to Emperor Komei's official biography, "'Komei Tenno ki", Emperor's doctors used to make regular announcement in terms of Emperor's health as 'Emperor's health record'.
According to Emperor Komei's official biography, "'Komei Tenno ki," the Emperor's doctors used to make regular announcements in terms of the Emperor's health as 'Emperor's health record.'
According to Emperor Komei's official biography, "Komei Tenno ki," the Emperor's doctors used to make regular announcements in terms of the Emperor's health as 'Emperor's health record.'

sen.j: これによれば、発症以降の天皇の病状は、一般的な痘瘡患者が回復に向かってたどるプロセスどおりに進行していることを示す「御順症」とされていた。
sen.e: According to this 'Emperor's health record', it was said '御順症'which meant the Emperor was getting better accordingly by following the standard process of someone had smallpox got better
sen.cmt: 御順症→[読み方, 定訳不明]
sen.e: According to this 'Emperor's health record,' it said '御順症'which meant the Emperor was getting better accordingly by following the standard process of someone who had smallpox and got better.
According to this 'Emperor's health record,' it said '御順症' which meant the Emperor was getting better accordingly by following the standard process of someone who had smallpox and got better.

sen.j: しかし、前述の伊良子光順の日記においては、翌25日の記録には、天皇が痰がひどく、藤木篤平と静顕が体をさすり、光順が膏薬を張り、班に関係なく昼夜寝所に詰めきりであったが、同日亥の刻（午後11時）過ぎに崩御された、と記されている。
sen.e: However, according to the record on the following day, on 25th of Mitsuoki IRAKO's diary which was mentioned previously, it was said that the Emperor had much phlegm and 藤木篤平 and 静顕 gave him a massage, and Mitsuoki put ointment on Emperor's body, all the doctors, mixed from different group, were watching Emperor closely during day and night, and then it said the Emperor died after eleven o'clock in the morning on the same day.

However, according to the record on the following day, on the 25th in Mitsuoki IRAKO's diary mentioned previously, it said that the Emperor had much phlegm and 藤木篤平 and 静顕 gave him a massage, and Mitsuoki applied ointment on Emperor's body, all the doctors, mixed from different groups, were watching the Emperor closely day and night, and then the Emperor died after eleven o'clock in the morning on the same day.

However, according to the record on the following day, on the 25th in Mitsuoki IRAKO's diary mentioned previously, it said that the Emperor had much phlegm and Atsuhira FUJIKI and Seiken gave him a massage, and Mitsuoki applied ointment on Emperor's body, all the doctors, mixed from different groups, were watching the Emperor closely day and night, and then the Emperor died after eleven o'clock in the morning on the same day.
sen.cmt: 藤木篤平、静顕 読み方不明ですが、一般的な読みで表記しました。

sen.j: 中山忠能の日記にも、「御九穴より御脱血」などと壮絶な天皇の病状が記されている。
sen.e: It was also mentioned in Tadayasu NAKAYAMA's diary in heretical way how the Emperor was suffering from the smallpox, 'the Emperor was bleeding from Kyuko (mouth, eyes, ears, urethral hall and the anus)'.
sen.cmt: 御九穴より御脱血→[定訳不明]
sen.e: It was also mentioned in Tadayasu NAKAYAMA's diary in a heretical way how the Emperor was suffering from smallpox, 'the Emperor was bleeding from Kyuko (mouth, eyes, ears, urethral hall and the anus).'

It was also mentioned in Tadayasu NAKAYAMA's diary in a heretical way how the Emperor was suffering from smallpox, 'the Emperor was bleeding from Kyuko (mouth, eyes, ears, urethral hall and the anus).'

sen.j: それでも天皇の喪は秘され、実際には命日となった25日にも、福井登の名前で「益御機嫌能被成為候（ますますご機嫌がよくなられました）」という内容の報告書が提出されている。
sen.e: Still the Emperor's death was not officially announced, even on the 25th, the day Emperor died, there was a journal reported by the name of 福井登, 'the Emperor was feeling better.'
Still the Emperor's death was not officially announced, even on the 25th, the day the Emperor died, there was a journal by the name of 福井登, that reported 'the Emperor was feeling better.'
Still the Emperor's death was not officially announced, even on the 25th, the day the Emperor died, there was a journal by the name of 福井登, that reported 'the Emperor was feeling better.'

sen.j: 天皇の崩御が公にされたのは29日になってからのことだった。
sen.e: It was on 29th when the death of the Emperor was officially announced.
It was on the 29th when the death of the Emperor was officially announced.
It was on the 29th when the death of the Emperor was officially announced.

tit.e: The theory of Emperor's assassination, an unnatural death
The theory of the Emperor's assassination, an unnatural death
The theory of the Emperor's assassination, an unnatural death

sen.j: 孝明天皇は前述の通り長年のあいだ悪性の痔に悩まされていたが、それ以外では至って壮健であり、前出の中山忠能日記にも「近年御風邪抔一向御用心モ不被為遊御壮健ニ被任趣存外之儀恐驚」（近年御風邪の心配など一向にないほどご壮健であらせられたので、痘瘡などと存外の病名を聞いて大変驚いた）との感想が記されている。
sen.e: Although Emperor Komei suffered from a malignant hemorrhoids for a long time, as it was previously mentioned, apart from this the Emperor was quite healthy and it was written in the Tadayasu NAKAYAMA's diary as it was mentioned before, he said, 'I was very shocked to know the Emperor suffered from unusual dieses like smallpox, since he had been very healthy and did not even had flue recently.'

Although Emperor Komei suffered from a malignant hemorrhoids for a long time, as it was previously mentioned, apart from this the Emperor was quite healthy and it was written in Tadayasu NAKAYAMA's diary, as mentioned before, he said, 'I was very shocked to know the Emperor suffered from unusual diseases like smallpox, since he had been very healthy and did not even get the flu recently.'

Although Emperor Komei suffered from a malignant hemorrhoids for a long time, as it was previously mentioned, apart from this the Emperor was quite healthy and it was written in Tadayasu NAKAYAMA's diary, as mentioned before, he said, 'I was very shocked to know the Emperor suffered from unusual diseases like smallpox, since he had been very healthy and did not even get the flu recently.'

sen.j: その天皇が数えで36歳の若さにしてあえなく崩御してしまったことから、直後からその死因に対する不審説が漏れ広がっていた。
sen.e: Because the Emperor with good health died young with thirty six years of age, counting in the old Japanese way, unexpectedly, there was suspicious rumor started spread out about the cause of his death just after he died.

Because the Emperor with good health died young at thirty six years of age, counting in the old Japanese way, unexpectedly, there was a suspicious rumor going around about the cause of his death just after he died.

Because the Emperor with good health died young at thirty six years of age, counting in the old Japanese way, unexpectedly, there was a suspicious rumor going around about the cause of his death just after he died.

sen.j: その後明治維新を過ぎると、世の中には皇国史観が形成され、皇室に関する疑惑やスキャンダルを公言する事はタブーとなり、学術的に孝明天皇の暗殺説を論ずる事は長く封印されたが、1940年（昭和15年）7月、日本医史学会関西支部大会の席上において、京都の婦人科医・佐伯理一郎が「天皇が痘瘡に罹患した機会を捉え、岩倉具視がその妹の女官・堀河紀子を操り、天皇に毒を盛った」旨の論説を発表している。
sen.e: After the Meii Restoration, Kokokushikan(emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto) was established in the society, it was prohibited to talk about suspicions and scandals about the Imperial family in public, it was sealed to talk about the theory of Emperor's assassination for a long time scholarly, but in July 1940, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Kyoto, Riichiro SAEKI reported his essay while he was attending at the Kansai Branch of Japan Society of Medical History, it was said, 'when the Emperor had smallpox, Tomomi IWAKURA ordered his younger sister and the lady-in-waiting, Motoko HOTIKAWA, to purposely gave poison to the Emperor.'

After the Meii Restoration, Kokokushikan (emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto) was established in society, it was prohibited to talk about suspicions and scandals in public concerning the Imperial family, it was prohibited to talk about the theory of Emperor's assassination for a long time, but in July 1940, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Kyoto, Riichiro SAEKI wrote in his essay while he was attending the Kansai Branch of the Japan Society of Medical History, that 'when the Emperor had smallpox, Tomomi IWAKURA ordered his younger sister and the lady-in-waiting, Motoko HORIKAWA, to purposely give poison to the Emperor.'

After the Meiji Restoration, Kokokushikan (emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto) was established in society, it was prohibited to talk about suspicions and scandals in public concerning the Imperial Family, it was prohibited to talk about the theory of Emperor's assassination for a long time, but in July 1940, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Kyoto, Riichiro SAEKI wrote in his essay while he was attending the Kansai Branch of the Japan Society of Medical History, that 'when the Emperor had smallpox, Tomomi IWAKURA ordered his younger sister and the lady-in-waiting, Motoko HORIKAWA, to purposely give poison to the Emperor.'

sen.j: そして、第二次世界大戦に日本が敗北し言論に対するタブーが霧散すると、俄然変死説が論壇をにぎわすようになる。
sen.e: After Japan lost the World War Ⅱ, when people had the freedom of speech back to the society, there was a theory of the Emperor's unnatural death came back on the world of criticism suddenly.
After Japan lost World War Ⅱ, when the freedom of speech was returned to society, the theory of the Emperor's unnatural death was suddenly back in the world of criticismy.
After Japan lost World War Ⅱ, when the freedom of speech was returned to society, the theory of the Emperor's unnatural death was suddenly back in the world of criticism.

sen.j: まず最初に学問的に暗殺説を論じたのは、『孝明天皇は病死か毒殺か』『孝明天皇と中川宮』などの論文を発表したねずまさしである。
sen.e: It was Masashi NEZU who scholarly firstly argued the the theory of Emperor's assassination, he published an essay of "Did Emperor Komei die of disease or poison?", " Emperor Komei and Nakagawanomiya"

It was Masashi NEZU who first argued scholarly about the theory of the Emperor's assassination, he published an essay of "Did Emperor Komei die of disease or poison?" "Emperor Komei and Nakagawanomiya"

It was Masashi NEZU who first argued scholarly about the theory of the Emperor's assassination, he published an essay of "Did Emperor Komei die of disease or poison?" "Emperor Komei and Nakagawanomiya"

sen.j: ねずは、典医たちが発表した「御容態書」のとおり天皇が順調に回復の道をたどっていたところが、一転急変して苦悶の果てに崩御したことを鑑み、その最期の病状から砒素による毒殺の可能性を推定。
sen.e: Nezu made an assumption that the possibility of the Emperor's death being poisoned by arsenic, after following 'the Emperor's health report' reported by Imperial doctors, which said that the Emperor was getting better accordingly, Nezu collate the record that all the sudden the Emperor died in agony.

Nezu assumed the possibility of the Emperor's death was caused by arsenic, after following 'the Emperor's health report' written by the Imperial doctors, that said the Emperor was getting better, Nezu collated the record that all of a sudden the Emperor died in agony.

Nezu assumed the possibility of the Emperor's death was caused by arsenic, after following 'the Emperor's health report' written by the Imperial doctors, that said the Emperor was getting better, Nezu collated the record that all of a sudden the Emperor died in agony.

sen.j: また犯人も前述の佐伯説と同様に岩倉首謀・堀河実行説を唱えた。
sen.e: He advocated the theory that IWAKURA planned the assassination of the Emperor and Horikawa carried it out, same theory as Saeki's, previously mentioned.
He put fourth the theory that IWAKURA planned the assassination of the Emperor and Horikawa carried it out, the same theory previously mentioned by Saeki.
He put fourth the theory that Iwakura planned the assassination of the Emperor and Horikawa carried it out, the same theory previously mentioned by Saeki.

sen.j: 1975年（昭和50年）から1977年（同52年）にかけ、前述の伊良子光順の拝診日記が、滋賀県で開業医を営む親族の伊良子光孝によって『滋賀県医師会報』に連載された。
sen.e: Between 1975 and 1977, the diary of the medical examination written by Mitsuoki IRAKO, which was previously mentioned, was serially published on "Shiga Medical Association newsletter" by his relative, 伊良子光孝 who runs a medical practice in Shiga Prefecture.

Between 1975 and 1977, the diary of medical examinations written by Mitsuoki IRAKO, previously mentioned, was serially published in the "Shiga Medical Association newsletter" by his relative, 伊良子光孝 who runs a medical practice in Shiga Prefecture.

Between 1975 and 1977, the diary of medical examinations written by Mitsuoki IRAKO, previously mentioned, was serially published in the "Shiga Medical Association newsletter" by his relative, 伊良子光孝 who runs a medical practice in Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: この日記の内容そのものはほとんどが客観的な記述で構成され、天皇の死因を特定できるような内容が記されているわけでもなく、光順自身が天皇の死因について私見を述べているようなものでもない。
sen.e: The most part of the writing content of this diary was established objectively, there was no content which can be specified why the Emperor died, or this was not an essay that Mitsuoki wrote his personal opinion about the cause of Emperor's death.

Most of the writing in this diary was objective, there was no content that can be specified as to why the Emperor died, this was not an essay where Mitsuoki wrote his personal opinion about the cause of the Emperor's death.

Most of the writing in this diary was objective, there was no content that can be specified as to why the Emperor died, this was not an essay where Mitsuoki wrote his personal opinion about the cause of the Emperor's death.

sen.j: だがこれを発表した光孝は、断定こそ避けているものの、ねずと同じく毒物による中毒死を推察させるコメントを解説文の中に残した。
sen.e: However 光孝 who published this diary, left his comment in the interpretive article of the possibility that the Emperor might have been poisoned and died although it was not concluded, but it was the same theory as Nezu's.
However 光孝 who published this diary, left his commentary about the possibility that the Emperor might have been poisoned and died although it was not conclusive, but it was the same theory as Nezu's.
However 光孝 who published this diary, left his commentary about the possibility that the Emperor might have been poisoned and died although it was not conclusive, but it was the same theory as Nezu's.

sen.j: また、そのほかにも学界において毒殺説を採る研究者は少なからずおり、1980年代初頭までは孝明天皇の死因について、毒殺を中心とした変死説が然るべき勢力を保っていた。
sen.e: There are a few a researchers who insisted the theory of Emperor being poisoned in the academic world, this theory of Emperor's unnatural death (being poisoned and died) was the dominant theory until early 1980's.
There are a few a researchers in the academic world who insisted on the theory was true about the Emperor being poisoned, the Emperor's unnatural death was the dominant theory until the early 1980's.
There are a few a researchers in the academic world who insisted on the theory was true about the Emperor being poisoned, the Emperor's unnatural death was the dominant theory until the early 1980's.

sen.j: そのほか、天皇が宮中で何者かに刺殺あるいは斬殺されたという説もみられ、「宮家の侍医が深夜呼び出されて御所に上がり、腹部を刺され血まみれになった孝明天皇と思われる貴人を手当てしたが甲斐無く絶命した」という型の話が数種流布している。
sen.e: Apart from this, there was another theory that the Emperor was killed by tying rope around his neck or stubbed to death by someone, there were many rumors like ' doctors of the house of an Imperial prince was called in midnight to the Imperial Palace and treated a nobleman (the Emperor) who presumably could have been emperor Komei, he was in blood after being stubbed around his stomach, although he was treated by the doctor, he died.'

Apart from this, there was another theory that the Emperor was killed by tying rope around his neck or by being stabbed to death by someone, there were many rumors like ' doctors of the household of an Imperial prince was called at midnight to the Imperial Palace who treated a nobleman (the Emperor) who presumably could have been emperor Komei, he was in blood after being stabbed around his stomach, although treated, he died.'

Apart from this, there was another theory that the Emperor was killed by tying rope around his neck or by being stabbed to death by someone, there were many rumors like 'doctors of the household of an Imperial prince was called at midnight to the Imperial Palace who treated a nobleman who presumably could have been emperor Komei, he was in blood after being stabbed around his stomach, although treated, he died.'

sen.j: しかし、原因不明の難病ならばまだしも、刺された事が明らかな状況でわざわざ外部の医者を呼ぶ事は不自然であるなど、その内容が毒殺説に比して荒唐無稽ということで、歴史研究者の間ではほとんど取るに足らないものとされた。
sen.e: However it was understandable if the Emperor had an incurable disease with unknown cause, it was not natural to call doctor from outside if the Emperor was apparently stubbed, so this theory was not so seriously considered to be true within historians since it was very unrealistic compare to the theory of Emperor being poisoned and died.

However it was understandable if the Emperor had an incurable disease with an unknown cause, it was not natural to call a doctor from outside if the Emperor was apparently stabbed, so this theory was not seriously considered to be true among historians since it was very unrealistic compared to the theory of the Emperor being killed by poison.

However it was understandable if the Emperor had an incurable disease with an unknown cause, it was not natural to call a doctor from outside if the Emperor was apparently stabbed, so this theory was not seriously considered to be true among historians since it was very unrealistic compared to the theory of the Emperor being killed by poison.
